questions.text: The patient has an infection of the cavernous sinus, involving the nerve located on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducens nerve, you will ask the patient to look in which direction?
questions.explanation:
Abducens Nerve (cranial nerve VI)

Type

Motor

Origin

Pons (lower border, opposite the pyramid of the medulla).

Course

 

Functional component
  • General somatic efferent fibres: Arise from the abducent nucleus in the pons and supply the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball.
  • General somatic afferent fibres carry proprioceptive sensations from the lateral rectus and terminate in the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

Supply

Lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball

Clinical aspect

Lesion or injury (elevated intracranial pressure) of the abducens nerve results in paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to:

  • Inability to abduct the eye (Option B)
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Convergent squint (due to the unopposed action of medial rectus)

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below.

What should be the subsequent course of action for a patient presenting with one eye displaying convergent squint and visual acuity of 6/60, while the other eye has no squint but also displays visual acuity of 6/60?
questions.explanation:
Type of Squint

Description

Management

Esotropia

Inward deviation of one or both eyes

Observation, glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery

Exotropia

Outward deviation of one or both eyes

Observation, glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery

Hypertropia

Upward deviation of one or both eyes

Observation, glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery

Hypotropia

Downward deviation of one or both eyes

Observation, glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery

Alternating

Switching eye deviation between the two eyes

Observation, glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery

Accommodative

Eye misalignment due to focusing effort (refractive error)

Glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery (rare cases)

Non-accommodative

Eye misalignment not due to focusing effort (neurological)

Observation, glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery

Congenital

Present at birth

Observation, glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery

Acquired

Develops later in life due to various causes

Treat underlying cause (glasses, patching, orthoptic exercises, surgery)

questions.text: In a 40-year-old patient with diabetes, a squint was observed. The secondary deviation was higher than the primary deviation during examination. The forced duction test yielded negative results. Which type of squint is expected to be predominant in this individual?
The movement lost on left gaze as depicted in the image is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Optic nerve (CN II)
  • Purely sensory
  • Senses the incoming light and image displayed on retina

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Innervates majority of the extraocular muscles
  • Motor innervation to the superior rectus muscle, medial rectus muscle, inferior rectus muscle, inferior oblique muscle, levator palpebrae superioris muscle, ciliary muscle, and the sphincter muscle.

Trochlear nerve (CN IV)
  • Motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle

Trigeminal Nerve (CN V)

  • Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the eye
  • Afferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Abducens Nerve (CN VI)
  • Motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle

Facial Nerve (CN VII)
  • Motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Efferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Sympathetic Nervous System
  • Long ciliary nerves: Innervates the pupillary dilator muscles causing mydriasis

Parasympathetic nervous system
  • Short ciliary nerves: Innervates the sphincter pupillae muscles causing miosis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the finding observed by a physician during an eye examination of a small child?
The chart depicted in the image is ______?
Identify the condition

What is the likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old girl presenting with decreased best corrected visual acuity in the right eye after a school vision screening revealed diminution of acuity in the right eye without any examination findings of the eye and visual pathway?
questions.explanation:
Type

Cause

Key Features

Strabismic Amblyopia

The brain suppresses input from one eye due to constant squint (strabismus).

Common cause; underdevelopment of vision in the deviated eye.

Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia

Hindered vision due to obstruction from early life (e.g., congenital cataracts, ptosis, dense central corneal opacity).

Lack of visual stimulation affects normal development.

Anisometropic Amblyopia

A significant difference in refractive error between eyes.

The brain favours the clearer eye, leading to amblyopia in the other.

Ametropic Amblyopia

High uncorrected refractive errors in both eyes.

Bilateral; is less severe compared to other types.

Meridional Amblyopia

Uncorrected astigmatism affecting specific visual meridians.

Affects one or both eyes depending on the astigmatism degree.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia in the right eye?
questions.correct_answer: C. Occlusion of the left eye
questions.explanation:
Amblyopia treatment should be started as early as possible (younger the child, better the prognosis). Amblyopia therapy works best when initiated in young children under 3 years of age and comprise:

Occlusion therapy (Option C): Occlusion of the sound (normal) eye to force use of amblyopic eye is the main stay in the treatment of amblyopia. Following methods are deployed,

  • Full-time occlusion: Up to 2 years, the occlusion should be done in 2:1, i.e. 2 days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye; at the age of 3 years, 3:1; at the age of 4 years, 4:1; At the age of 5 years, 5:1; and after the age of 6 years 6:1.
  • Part-time occlusion: 4-6 hours/day, as shown by Amblyopia Treatment Study (ATS), and is as effective as full-time occlusion.
  • Maintenance occlusion: After vision equalization, part-time occlusion continues until at least 8 years of age.
  • Ensure no media opacity or refractive errors before starting occlusion therapy.

Other Methods:

  • Penalization: Blurring vision in the sound eye with atropine or over-plus lenses.
  • Computerized Home Vision Therapy: Uses specially designed software as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
  • Pharmacologic Manipulation
    • Levodopa/Carbidopa: Studied as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
    • Other agents: Citicoline and omega fatty acids
  • Pleoptics: Pleoptic exercises are done to improve foveal fixation, though less commonly used now.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with left eyelid drooping and experiencing double vision. Upon examination, it was observed that the pupil in the affected eye was dilated. The following eye movement examination was conducted. Which nerve is most likely injured in this case?

Muscle

Secondary Actions

None

Lateral Rectus

Abduction (moves eye outward)

None

Abducens nerve (CN VI)

Superior Rectus

Elevation (moves eye upward) (Option B ruled out)

Intorsion (inward rotation), Adduction

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

Inferior Rectus

Depression (moves eye downward)

Extorsion (outward rotation), Adduction

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

Superior Oblique

Intorsion (inward rotation)

Depression, Abduction

Trochlear nerve (CN IV)

Inferior Oblique

Extorsion (outward rotation)

(Option C & D ruled out)

Elevation, Abduction

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

Optic nerve (CN II)
  • Purely sensory
  • Senses the incoming light and image displayed on retina

Oculomotor nerve (CN III) (Option C)
  • Innervates majority of the extraocular muscles
  • Motor innervation to the superior rectus muscle, medial rectus muscle, inferior rectus muscle, inferior oblique muscle, levator palpebrae superioris muscle, ciliary muscle, and the sphincter muscle.

Trochlear nerve (CN IV) (Option D)
  • Motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle

Trigeminal Nerve (CN V)

  • Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the eye
  • Afferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Abducens Nerve (CN VI) (Option A)

  • Motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle

Facial Nerve (CN VII)
  • Motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Efferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Sympathetic Nervous System
  • Long ciliary nerves: Innervates the pupillary dilator muscles causing mydriasis

Parasympathetic nervous system
  • Short ciliary nerves: Innervates the sphincter pupillae muscles causing miosis

questions.text: The cover-uncover test is performed to diagnose various eye conditions. Which of the following is not detected by this test?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Identifies latent deviations or tropias.
  • ↳ latent deviations or tropias.
  • ↳ Procedure: Cover one eye and then observe the covered eye when the cover is removed. If the eye reverts to fixation, it indicates a phoria or intermittent tropia . If the eye remains deviated, it suggests a tropia with fixation preference for the fellow eye.
  • ↳ Procedure:
  • ↳ Cover one eye and then observe the covered eye when the cover is removed. If the eye reverts to fixation, it indicates a phoria or intermittent tropia . If the eye remains deviated, it suggests a tropia with fixation preference for the fellow eye.
  • ↳ Cover one eye and then observe the covered eye when the cover is removed.
  • ↳ If the eye reverts to fixation, it indicates a phoria or intermittent tropia .
  • ↳ phoria or intermittent tropia
  • ↳ If the eye remains deviated, it suggests a tropia with fixation preference for the fellow eye.
  • ↳ tropia with fixation preference for the fellow eye.
  • ↳ Alternate Cover Test: Detects phorias by dissociating the visual axes.
  • ↳ Alternate Cover Test:
  • ↳ Alternate covering each eye to maximize visual axis dissociation. Care must be taken to permit time for each eye to reside behind the cover (the cover must not be “fanned” before the eyes). Use prisms to quantify phorias or tropias. If measurements are unclear, estimate the midpoint between defined movements.
  • ↳ Alternate covering each eye to maximize visual axis dissociation.
  • ↳ Care must be taken to permit time for each eye to reside behind the cover (the cover must not be “fanned” before the eyes).
  • ↳ Use prisms to quantify phorias or tropias. If measurements are unclear, estimate the midpoint between defined movements.
  • ↳ Lateral Nystagmus (Option C): Nystagmus is involuntary, rhythmic eye movements. The cover-uncover test might exacerbate nystagmus, though it is not the primary test for detecting it.
  • ↳ Lateral Nystagmus (Option C):

questions.text: What is the probable cause of uniocular diplopia in a young boy who has experienced trauma to his right eye?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - I

Diplopia

Causes

Binocular diplopia
  • Paralysis or paresis of the extraocular muscles (Commonest cause)
  • Displacement of one eyeball either due to the lesion in the orbit and the fracture of the orbital wall.
  • Mechanical restriction of the ocular movement caused by the thick pterygium, symblepharon and thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Deviation of rays of light in one eye as caused by Decentred spectacles.
  •  Anisometropia

Uniocular diplopia
  • Subluxated clear lens
  • Subluxated intraocular lens
  • Double pupil due to congenital anomaly or large peripheral iridectomy or iridodialysis.
  • Incipient cataract
